improved skills / knowledge of 75 senior police officers on command and control tactics. • Eqipped 3 police stations, 4 police posts and 2 central police stations; prosecution office and rural court with ICT / furniture items to enhance functionality; enhanced the capacities of 87 lawyers of Bar Association Associations in diferent states; activated the criminal justice forum to address justice snd security concerns; created a platform to engage on building confidence and trust in security organs among members of the communities; validation exercise to enhance national ownership of ROL interventions in the wake of UNAMIDs exit. • furnished 4 human rights resource centres and eqipped with generators each together with a State Judiciary and 2 human rights libraries to enhance functionality. • A five-year National Strategy for the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) was produced, under which a comprehensive institutional and legal reform action plan is agreed upon to enable and facilitate the ministry’s critical role in realizing the democratic transition in Sudan, with due respect to principles of inclusion, transparency, accessibility and respect for human rights. • A five-year National Strategy for judicial reform was developed by the conference of judges (awaiting validation), identifying the areas of reform and means of implementation, including restructuring of judicial organs, securing its independence, mainstreaming gender equality and enhancing access to justice for all (the judicial conference was attended by 120 judges and justices from all States). • Three laws passed by the government for the establishment of the three commissions named by the Constitutional Document and Juba Peace Agreement as top priorities, to lead the transitional agenda on peace and security, accountability and transparency, namely the Peace Commission, Transitional Justice Commission and Anti-corruption Commission. Formation of these commission was determent as well for Sudan eligibility for the international community support, financially and politically. • Three draft legislations were finalized by the MOJ and partially consulted on with the support of UNDP, for the formation the Human Right Commission, Constitution-Making Process and Commission and Election Commission. Three workshops were organized for the political parties, civil society organizations and experts on each area for each draft in Khartoum; arrangement for the consultation meetings in the 17 States were made awaiting government formation. • A baseline study assessing Sudan legal System, conducted by a national expert in support of MOJ, was produce. The study discussed the discrepancy within the legal system and proposed a roadmap and strategy for the reform, alongside a draft legislation for the Legal Reform Commission. • In-depth analysis of the Political Parties Registration Act and Civil Society Regulation Act were produced with the support of international expert, identifying the gaps and weaknesses in each act and propose areas for reform, as strengthening the role of both is very critical in the transition to democracy.
